conclusion: To solve the problem, we need to analyze the forces acting on the sled and the child system.
A child with a mass of 30kg is sitting on a sled with a mass of 10kg.
The combined weight of the child and sled is given by (m_child + m_sled)g.

premise: Mass of the child m_child = 30 kg, Mass of the sled m_sled = 10 kg
Total mass m_total = 40 kg, g = 10 m/s^2
conclusion: Total weight W = m_total g = 40 x 10 = 400 N
An adult pulls the sled with a force of 100N at an angle of 37° above the horizontal.
The pulling force F is applied at an angle θ = 37° above the horizontal.

premise: Magnitude of the pulling force F = 100 N, sin37° = 0.6
conclusion: Vertical component of the pulling force F sin θ = 100 x 0.6 = 60 N

premise: Magnitude of the pulling force F = 100 N, cos37° = 0.8
conclusion: Horizontal component of the pulling force F cos θ = 100 x 0.8 = 80 N
The normal force N is the force exerted by the ground on the sled, which balances the vertical components of the forces.
Since the sled moves at a constant speed, the net force in the vertical direction must be zero.

premise: Net vertical force is zero, Total weight W = 400 N, Vertical component of the pulling force F sin θ = 60 N
conclusion: Normal force N = W - F sin θ = 400 N - 60 N = 340 N
